body: @tetron Thanks! We just need tests for the `ex_fetch_power_state=False` branch to ensure coverage does not decrease.
Thank you! Merged in trunk.

@pquentin Great!! As far as I'm concerned, this fixes the issue.

Just a minor note... Maybe `_get_size_price()` should directly return None instead of raising an exception. In that way, the behavior would be consistent across the codebase. I mean, just moving the `try..except` block from `list_sizes()` to `_get_size_price()`. What do you think?
Ah, yes, that would be better! I'll do that.
Thanks @tetron @ldipenti this is now merged in trunk.

Thinking a bit more about it, that would affect other drivers. I would not want to return None silently in those cases because we would not be alerted of an issue in tests. The change as it is currently only affects EC2.

@tonybaloney Clearly this was done for Hacktoberfest last year. Is this useful? How do ensure it stays in sync? The English README still has a PyPI download counter even though this statistic has long been disabled by PyPI.
@haucke For what it's worth, the request was to change the file name, not the pull request title.
Great, thanks @pquentin !
Hmmm... Needs to support Python 2.6. So how are other tests using `assertRaises` as a context manager? :thinking:

Thanks for the PR, it's the best way to get feedback. Sorry that you did not get answers on the mailing lists and on JIRA, we don't have enough contributors to help with all of this. I don't know if I'll be able to review your PR myself and would appreciate some help: there's no need to be a commiter to review a pull request!

With regards to documentation, you already have docstrings, which is great. You will also need a page specific to the storage driver, see docs/storage/drivers for examples.
Also make sure that the continuous integration passes.

> Also make sure that the continuous integration passes.

Yeah, I was wondering about how to tackle that.

My implementation relies on the Tencent Python SDK as a 3rd party package, but it's probably not desirable to have it as a "global" dependency for users that don't want to use this storage provider.

What's the recommended approach for such external dependencies?

Oh, I had not noticed that. As you have seen, libcloud does not use external dependencies for individual drivers, you would have to reimplement the useful parts of qcloud_cos for this. While this means we have to reinvent the wheel, it's often not that bad because using the HTTP API is usually not much harder than using a Python wrapper around it. And having minimal dependencies in requests is an important feature of the project.

Wrapping qcloud_cos to make it look libcloud-like is valuable, but it's just not something that should be integrated in libcloud. Sorry about that.

To answer to the question more directly: we use fixtures and mocks for tests, look at the other drivers to see how it's done.

Thanks for pointing me at the right direction!

> To answer to the question more directly: we use fixtures and mocks for tests, look at the other drivers to see how it's done.

Yeah, I noticed that. My tests are based on patching out the actual qcloud_cos client (returning canned responses), but it still requires importing stuff from that package.

I understand I should reimplement the relevant parts from qcloud_cos instead of depending on it, thanks.
